Negri v. Stop & Shop Cos., 383 Mass. 370.raw_text: Negri v. Stop & Shop Cos., 383 Mass. 370 (1981) (premises liability principles)
Negri v. Stop & Shop Cos., 383 Mass. 370.proposition: - Negri v. Stop & Shop Cos., 383 Mass. 370 (1981) (premises liability principles)
Negri v. Stop & Shop Cos., 383 Mass. 370.support_reasoning: The opinion is Black v. Chase (a Massachusetts trust/prudent investor case), not Negri v. Stop & Shop, and it concerns trustee investment standards and probate practice, not premises liability. It does not discuss duties of landowners to invitees, slip-and-fall standards, or any other premises liability principles. Therefore it cannot support a proposition about premises liability under Negri v. Stop & Shop.
Negri v. Stop & Shop Cos., 383 Mass. 370.relevant_excerpt: In Harvard College v. Amory, 9 Pick. 446, 461 (1830), this court rejected contentions that insurance and manufacturing stocks were not proper trust investments. We said: “All that can be required of a trustee to invest, is, that he shall conduct himself faithfully and exercise a sound discretion. He is to observe how men of prudence, discretion and intelligence manage their own affairs, not in regard to speculation, but in regard to the permanent disposition of their funds...”

Gadomski v. Saint Vincent Hospital, 430.raw_text: Gadomski v. Saint Vincent Hospital, 430 Mass. 105 (1999) (duty and negligence principles)
Gadomski v. Saint Vincent Hospital, 430.proposition: - Gadomski v. Saint Vincent Hospital, 430 Mass. 105 (1999) (duty and negligence principles)
Gadomski v. Saint Vincent Hospital, 430.case_name: Walsh v. Secretary of the Commonwealth
Gadomski v. Saint Vincent Hospital, 430.support_reasoning: The proposition characterizes Gadomski v. Saint Vincent Hospital as a duty and negligence case, but the provided opinion is not Gadomski at all; it is a Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court election-law/initiative-petition opinion discussing Hurst, G.L. c. 53, § 22A, art. 48, and First Amendment burdens. It deals with exact-copy requirements for initiative petitions and related constitutional analysis, not tort duty or negligence principles. Therefore, this opinion does not support the claimed duty/negligence proposition and appears to be a mismatched or mis-cited case text.
Gadomski v. Saint Vincent Hospital, 430.relevant_excerpt:
“We conclude that the Secretary properly excluded the petition forms and we should adhere to the rule announced in Hurst.
…
The Legislature has instructed that ‘exact copies’ of petition blanks provided by the Secretary may be used to gather signatures. Exact copy means exact copy. … The statute does not permit any alterations of forms, whether by copying machine, petition circulator, or petition signer.”

Ayash v. Dana-Farber Cancer Inst., 443 M.raw_text: Ayash v. Dana-Farber Cancer Inst., 443 Mass. 367 (2005) (causation and damages principles)
Ayash v. Dana-Farber Cancer Inst., 443 M.proposition: - Ayash v. Dana-Farber Cancer Inst., 443 Mass. 367 (2005) (causation and damages principles)
Ayash v. Dana-Farber Cancer Inst., 443 M.support_reasoning: The proposition is very general, indicating the case is cited for causation and damages principles. Ayash squarely discusses both: (1) causation, especially in the retaliation analysis under G.L. c. 151B (the link between protected activity and nonrenewal of employment), and (2) damages, including what categories are recoverable on an implied covenant claim, the non‑applicability of the charitable cap to c. 151B damages, and the need for a new trial when damages are not apportioned among multiple theories. Thus the case is appropriate authority for general causation and damages principles.
Ayash v. Dana-Farber Cancer Inst., 443 M.relevant_excerpt:
“The plaintiff’s evidence easily meets the standard for proof of causation in retaliation claims under G. L. c. 151B. See Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harvard College, 432 Mass. 107, 114 (2000)…
…Our cases establish that, in awarding damages for breach of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing, the goal is to compensate an employee for past services and to deny the employer ‘any readily definable, financial windfall’ resulting from the breach… The only damages to which the plaintiff is entitled are for economic losses suffered as a result of the hospital’s failure to provide written notice of her right to a hearing.”}

McDonough v. Bingham, 358 Mass. 93 (1970.case_name: Aiello v. Commissioner of Public Welfare
McDonough v. Bingham, 358 Mass. 93 (1970.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether welfare recipients are constitutionally or statutorily entitled to payment of counsel fees for administrative ‘fair hearings’ under G.L. c. 118 and c. 118D, not landowner liability. It does not address premises liability, duties of landowners, or any tort principles related to land ownership, so it cannot support a proposition about landowner liability.
McDonough v. Bingham, 358 Mass. 93 (1970.relevant_excerpt: “The sole issue before the judge was ‘whether the [department must order the respective cities’ welfare departments as a matter of law to pay the reasonable counsel fees for services rendered at “fair hearings” held by the department.’ … We perceive no violation of the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment in not providing an attorney for an appellant at a welfare hearing.”

McPherson v. Boston, 280 Mass. 1 (1932).raw_text: McPherson v. Boston, 280 Mass. 1 (1932) (duty of care)
McPherson v. Boston, 280 Mass. 1 (1932).proposition: - McPherson v. Boston, 280 Mass. 1 (1932) (duty of care)
McPherson v. Boston, 280 Mass. 1 (1932).support_reasoning: The provided opinion concerns land registration, construction of deeds, and implied easements; it does not analyze or articulate any rule about a tort duty of care. Since the proposition only repeats the case name followed by “(duty of care)” without any substantive statement, and no duty-of-care discussion appears in this excerpt, the case as presented does not support that labeled proposition. It appears mis-cited if intended as authority on duty of care.
McPherson v. Boston, 280 Mass. 1 (1932).relevant_excerpt: "There is no implied reservation of an easement in case one sells part of his land over which he has previously exercised a privilege in favor of the land which he retains unless the burden is apparent, continuous and strictly necessary for the enjoyment of the land retained. Carbrey v. Willis, 7 Allen, 364. Sullivan v. Ryan, 130 Mass. 116. O’Brien v. Murphy, 189 Mass. 353. Apsey v. Nash, 229 Mass. 77."

Hurley v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.relevant_excerpt: Because credibility was pivotal to the case, and because it can be inferred from the jury’s acquittal of the defendant on the aggravated rape and rape charges, and their acquittal of the codefendant on all charges, that the jury did not fully credit the complainant’s testimony, we conclude that the erroneous exclusion of the record requires a new trial.
